title: 114_s1109
content: The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" requires federal agencies to provide information on settlement agreements. The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" mandates that federal agencies disclose details of settlement agreements, including those involving alleged violations of federal laws requiring payments of at least $1,000,000 by non-federal entities. The term 'entity within the Federal Government' includes federal officers or employees acting officially. 'Non-Federal person' refers to individuals not part of the Federal Government. The term 'non-Federal person' refers to individuals not part of the Federal Government. Rule making is defined under section 551(5). Executive agencies must publicly list covered settlement agreements online. The covered settlement agreement must include the date, names of parties, description of claims, and payment obligations for each party involved. The settlement agreement outlines the total amount each party is obligated to pay, including any specified penalties or fines. The covered settlement agreement specifies the non-deductible amount under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and where the collected amounts will be deposited. The Executive agency must disclose information on settlement agreements and ensure confidentiality provisions are followed. The head of each Executive agency must ensure that information on covered settlement agreements is publicly available for at least 5 years, with a copy of the agreement available for at least 1 year. The head of an Executive agency must ensure that information on covered settlement agreements is publicly available for at least 5 years, with a copy of the agreement available for at least 1 year. If confidentiality is needed for a covered settlement agreement, a public statement must be issued explaining why it is necessary to protect the public interest of the United States. The text discusses the requirements for written public statements regarding covered settlement agreements, specifying the portions of the amount to be paid by a non-Federal person. It emphasizes the need to protect confidentiality in such agreements to outweigh the public's interest in knowing about the conduct of the Federal Government and the expenditure of Federal resources. The text outlines the requirements for covered settlement agreements, including specifying non-deductible fines under Federal law and detailing actions or payments by non-Federal persons. The text outlines the disclosure requirements for covered settlement agreements, including non-deductible fines under Federal law and payments to non-Federal persons. Confidentiality provisions may apply, and annual reporting to Congress is mandated for Executive agencies involved in such agreements. The Executive agency must report to Congress on covered settlement agreements entered into during the previous fiscal year, including the number of agreements, confidentiality terms, and total payments to non-Federal persons. The Executive agency must report to Congress on settlement agreements, including confidentiality terms, total payments to non-Federal persons, and the number of agreements involving regulatory action or changes. The report must be made publicly available on the agency's website. The Executive agency must report settlement agreements to Congress, including payment details and regulatory actions. The report will be publicly available on the agency's website in a searchable format. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress on how Executive agencies determine the confidentiality of settlement agreements. Recommendations for increasing transparency while protecting legitimate interests will be included. The Senate passed this on September 21, 2015.
